column14: To walk around a place with no clear direction or purpose. With "W"
column15: We wandered round the old town for hours.

column14: Feeling entertained or finding something funny.
column15: They were amused by his stories.

column14: A sudden loud noise, often caused by an impact or explosion.
column15: Did you hear that bang ? It sounded like a gun.

column14: To force air out of the mouth or through an object.
column15: I hate when people blow their nose in public.

column14: Mechanical devices used to slow down or stop a vehicle.
column15: The car stopped with a screech of brakes.

column14: A low continuous humming sound.
column15: I could hear the buzz of a fly.

column14: A sudden loud noise, often caused by an impact or accident.
column15: She heard the loud crash of a tree falling down.

column14: To make a prolonged squeaky sound, like an old door or floorboard.
column15: I heard a floorboard creak and I knew she was coming in late.

column14: Firm and fresh in texture, making a crunching sound when eaten or stepped on. With "C"
column15: I love walking through the crisp snow.

column14: A sound made when something is crushed or broken under pressure.
column15: I love hearing the crunch of my feet walking through the snow.

column14: To fall in small drops, as a liquid from a faucet.
column15: Please turn the tap off properly or it will drip .

column14: Feeling afraid or scared.
column15: Don’t be frightened . The dog won’t hurt you.

column14: To laugh in a high-pitched, often nervous way, like children reacting to a silly joke or someone embarrassed in a quiet room.
column15: They giggled nervously as they waited for their turn.

column14: To make a low sound of pain or discomfort. With "G".
column15: He groaned with pain.

column14: A sharp, prolonged "s" sound, like that of a snake.
column15: Did you hear the snake’s hiss ?

column14: To sound a car horn or an owl's call.
column15: I hate people who hoot at me when I slow down at an amber light.

column14: To make a continuous low sound, often while singing without words.
column15: I began to hum along with the music.
column52: Curso::1C1::File_4 Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice Voc::Sound Voc::Music Voc::Sing Voc::Smut Voc::Sound Voc::Speaking-Talking

column14: To speak in a low, unclear voice, like someone talking under their breath or responding sleepily.
column15: She mumbled a few words and left.

column14: To shake and make a series of short, sharp sounds.
column15: Every time a bus goes by, the windows rattle .

column14: Feeling reassured after anxiety or stress is removed.
column15: She sounded relieved when I told her I had got a job.

column14: A loud, deep sound, like that of a crowd or a lion.
column15: We could hear the roar of the crowd in the football stadium.
column52: Curso::1C1::File_4 Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice Voc::Animals Voc::Animals::EN-Animals Voc::Animals::PT-Animais Voc::Sound Voc::Sound

column14: To cry out in a loud, high-pitched voice, usually in fear or pain, like a person reacting to a sudden scare or someone in distress.
column15: The boy screamed when he fell.
column52: Curso::1C1::File_4 Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice Voc::Sound Voc::Physical_Pain Voc::Scream Voc::Sound Voc::Speaking-Talking

column14: A sharp, high-pitched sound, often unpleasant.
column15: I heard the screech of brakes as the bus driver tried to stop.

column14: To exhale deeply, often to express relief or frustration, like after a long day of work or when receiving disappointing news.
column15: He sighed deeply at the thought.
column52: Curso::1C1::File_4 Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice Voc::Sound Voc::Loss-Pain Voc::Love Voc::Smut Voc::Sound Voc::Speaking-Talking

column14: To shut a door or other object forcefully.
column15: Please don’t slam the door.

column14: To drink or eat noisily by sucking in liquid or food.
column15: It’s rude to slurp your soup.

column14: To inhale sharply through the nose, often when trying to smell something.
column15: Don’t sniff! Get a tissue and blow your nose!

column14: To breathe noisily while sleeping.
column15: I can’t share a room with you if you snore .

column14: To cry with convulsive catching of the breath.
column15: A child was sobbing loudly when I walked in.
column52: Curso::1C1::File_4 Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice Voc::Sound Voc::Cry Voc::Loss-Pain Voc::Physical_Pain Voc::Sound

column14: To speak with involuntary pauses and repetitions due to nervousness. Generally a temporary speech disruption, rather than a chronic condition. Common in UK
column15: My friend stammers when he gets nervous and it’s hard to understand him.

column14: Often refers to a habitual speech disorder where a person repeats sounds or syllables (e.g., "I-I-I can't go"). More common in the USA.
column15:
His anxiety affected his speech and he stuttered into the microphone.
Can also refer to mechanical malfunctions: "The engine stuttered before starting."

column14: To strike lightly, often with fingers or a small object.
column15: When I’m nervous I often tap my fingers on the table.

column14: Feeling extreme fear.
column15: I was terrified when they told me I had to do another test.

column14: A short, sharp sound, like that made by a clock.
column15: This clock has a very loud tick .

column14: A sequence of musical notes forming a melody.
column15: Please stop humming that tune .

column14: To speak in a soft, hushed voice.
column15: It’s rude to whisper.

column14: To produce a high-pitched sound by forcing air through pursed lips or a device.
column15: I can whistle a little bit, but I can’t really whistle a whole song.

column14: To shout loudly, often in anger or excitement.
column15: Please don’t yell at me. It wasn’t my fault.

column14: Referring to a sound that is high in frequency.
column15: I can’t stand his high-pitched voice.

column14: A sudden loud noise, often caused by an impact or explosion, like a gunshot or a firecracker.
To force air out of the mouth or through an object, like when blowing out candles or into a whistle.
A low continuous humming sound, like that of a bee or an electrical appliance.
A short, sharp sound, like a camera shutter or a computer mouse being pressed.
A sudden loud noise, often caused by an impact or accident, like a car hitting a barrier or waves against rocks.
Firm and fresh in texture, making a crunching sound when eaten or stepped on, like dry autumn leaves or a cracker.
A sound made when something is crushed or broken under pressure, like biting into a potato chip or walking on gravel.
A low sound of pain or discomfort, like someone lifting a heavy object or reacting to bad news.
A sharp, high-pitched sound, often unpleasant, like tires skidding on pavement or a hawk’s cry.
The sound of scattering liquid forcefully, causing droplets to fly, like jumping into a pool or dropping a rock in water.
A continuous, loud rattling noise caused by objects striking each other, like dropped metal utensils or a falling stack of plates.
A soft, low, and melodic sound, often of singing or murmuring, like a lullaby or a love song.
A short, forceful exhalation, often indicating frustration or exertion, like a sigh of annoyance or exhaustion after running.
A persistent, forceful pounding sound or sensation, like construction work or a loud heartbeat from anxiety.
The sound of something breaking without separating completely, like a tree branch snapping or a whip cracking.
The sound of a stringed instrument produced by brushing fingers or a pick across the strings, like a guitarist playing an acoustic song.
A loud, sharp sound made by metal striking metal.
column15:
The clank of the knight's armor echoed through the castle halls.
The clanking of ODM gear echoed through the ruins as the Scouts maneuvered between buildings.

column8: Som baixo e ameaçador de cães ou animais ferozes.
column14: A tangle or knot, or a growling sound made by an angry animal.
column15:
The director’s snarl warned everyone that rehearsals were not going well.
The Titan let out a deep snarl before lunging at the soldiers.
column52: Curso::1C1::Vocabulary-Bank::Sounds-and-Human-Voice My-Choice::FanFics::OC::Predatory-Love My_Mess::Multi Voc::Animals Voc::Animals::EN-Animals Voc::Animals::PT-Animais Voc::AOT Voc::My_Choice Voc::Sound Voc::Speaking-Talking

column14: A job or situation with no prospects for advancement.
column15: She got a dead-end job at the local factory.

column14: Financially comfortable or prosperous.
column15: His family are quite well-off.

column14: Equipped with a system that cools or regulates indoor temperature.
column15: In the summer, I spend most of my time in air‑conditioned buildings.

column14: Not harmful to the environment.
column15: Is your new fridge eco-friendly ?

column14: Activities outside the regular curriculum of school or college.
column15: My son does lots of extra-curricular activities after school, like cooking and tennis.

column14: Describing shoes with tall, raised heels.
column15: How can you wear high-heeled shoes on a trekking trip?

column14: Designed to reduce the amount of work needed.
column15: The washing machine was probably my mum’s favourite labour-saving device.

column14: Having a profound effect on someone's life.
column15: Being in an accident was a life-changing experience for him.

column14: Inexpensive; affordable.
column15: Have you ever travelled on a low-cost airline?

column14: Of limited size or extent.
column15: Small-scale pleasures make me very content with my life.

column14: Acting in a polite and disciplined manner.
column15: Children who are not well-behaved will be asked to leave.

column14: Familiar to many people; famous.
column15: We went to a fantastic exhibition by a well-known artist.

column14: No longer usable due to excessive wear or use.
column15: You need to replace those running shoes. They’re worn out.

column14: A small bubble on the skin filled with fluid, often caused by friction or burns.
column15: These shoes have given me blisters.

column14: A dark mark on the skin caused by a blow or impact that breaks blood vessels.
column15:
I fell down and got a bruise on my arm.
Mikasa ended up pressed up against a wall, an impertinent elbow jabbed into her throat, her senior pressed up against her, forming bruises marring the usually stoic expressions of the pair.

column14: A common viral infection affecting the nose and throat, usually causing sneezing and coughing.
column15: I’ve got a headache and a sore throat. I think I’ve caught a cold .

column14: An illness caused by consuming contaminated food, leading to nausea and vomiting.
column15: We all got food poisoning after eating in that restaurant.

column14: A doctor who provides general medical treatment and advice.
column15: I think you should go and see your GP as soon as possible.

column14: A medical emergency where blood flow to the heart is blocked, causing damage to heart tissue.
column15: He was only 40, but suffered a heart attack . He’s going to need to watch his diet from now on.

column14: A medical doctor specializing in mental health and the treatment of mental disorders.
column15: As a psychiatrist, he was experienced in treating mental health conditions.

column14: A skin condition characterized by red, itchy, or swollen patches.
column15: If I eat peanuts, I come out in a rash .

column14: Unwanted or unexpected reactions to a drug or treatment.
column15: All drugs have side-effects. Some of them can be quite bad.

column14: A doctor with advanced training in a specific area of medicine.
column15: Her GP referred her to a specialist.

column14: Describing an injury in which ligaments are stretched or torn, usually in a joint.
column15: I couldn't walk for a week due to a sprained ankle.

column14: A medical condition caused by interrupted blood flow to the brain, leading to paralysis or speech issues.
column15: The stroke left him paralysed.

column14: A doctor who performs operations.
column15: Do you know which surgeon will be operating on you?

column14: An infectious disease caused by the influenza virus, leading to fever, body aches, and fatigue.
column15: She’s off sick today. I think she’s got the flu .

column14: An illness affecting the throat, often caused by bacteria or viruses.
column15: My sister needed antibiotics to get rid of a very bad throat infection .

column14: Medical care given to a patient to relieve or cure an illness or injury.
column15: Doctors are very careful what treatment they give to patients.

column14: Used to tell someone to be more independent, active, or engaged in meaningful activities.
column15: He’s in his 40s and still living with his parents. He needs to get a life .

column14: To hurry up or start moving faster.
column15: You should get a move on or you’ll miss the train.

column14: To travel or move from place to place, especially in a city.
column15: The best way to get around this city is by bike.

column14: To avoid punishment or consequences for doing something wrong.
column15: I tried to cheat in an exam once, but I didn’t get away with it.

column14: To return a call or respond to someone later.
column15: Please leave a message and we’ll get back to you as soon as possible.

column14: To fall behind schedule or in completing work.
column15: Let me know if you get behind with your work and I’ll help you.

column14: To manage or survive, often with limited resources.
column15: My salary is not enough to get by on .

column14: To feel sad or depressed.
column15: Does the bad weather ever get you down ?

column14: To contact or reach someone.
column15: I need to speak to Lou, but I can’t get hold of her.

column14: To start being involved in something, such as a career or activity.
column15: What’s the best way to get into politics?

column14: To find oneself in a difficult or problematic situation.
column15: You’ll get into trouble with your mum if she finds out you took her car.

column14: [informal] [Phr. V] To become older, or comparatively older; to age.
column15:
Your grandfather must be getting on a bit. Isn't he in his 80s now?
We are both getting on a bit

column14: To organize oneself and become more efficient or responsible.
column15: She needs to get her act together and start looking for a job.

column14: To succeed in making things happen according to one's own wishes.
column15: She’s quite bossy and tends to get her own way .

column14: To develop a very good and friendly relationship quickly.
column15: I introduced them last month and now they get on like a house on fire .

column14: To irritate or annoy someone.
column15: I find children really irritating. They just get on my nerves.

column14: To continue doing something, especially work.
column15: I’ll leave you now. I need to get on with some work .

column14: To avoid doing something, often a responsibility.
column15: My brother always gets out of doing his share of the housework.

column14: To move aside to allow passage or progress.
column15: He wouldn’t get out of the way , so I got stuck behind him.

column14: To recover from something, especially an illness or emotional distress.
column15: It took him more than a year to get over their break-up.

column14: Used to tell someone to be realistic or practical.
column15: You want a well-paid job in a big company, but you won’t even do your homework. Get real!

column14: To remove or dispose of something unwanted.
column15: I can’t get rid of that painting because it was a wedding present.

column14: To have the opportunity to do something.
column15: I didn’t get the chance to speak to him.

column14: To form an idea or opinion about something or someone.
column15: Did you get the impression they didn’t like our present?

column14: To understand and appreciate a joke.
column15: Everyone laughed except you. Didn’t you get the joke ?

column14: To understand what is being communicated, often indirectly.
column15: I told him to leave us alone, but he didn’t get the message .

column14: To successfully communicate with someone.
column15: It is very difficult to get through to him – he just doesn't seem to understand.

column14: To meet or gather with someone, often socially.
column15: How often do you get together with your extended family?

column14: To become familiar with someone or something over time.
column15: I’m sure you’ll like him once you get to know him.

column14: To take revenge on someone.
column15: I’ll get my own back on him one day and take revenge.

column14: To make no progress or fail to achieve results.
column15: I’m not getting anywhere with this crossword. It's too hard.

column14: To book or catch a plane to travel.
column15: I had to get a flight a day after a plane crash. I almost cancelled it!

column14: To have a room improved or redecorated.
column15: We're getting the bathroom decorated at the moment.

column14: To be discovered while doing something wrong or illegal.
column15: I cheated in an exam once, but luckily I didn’t get caught.

column14: To make someone feel sad or depressed.
column15: We're having so many family problems at the moment, it's really getting me down .

column14: To have a good relationship with someone.
column15: We get on very well most of the time.

column14: To receive gifts, especially on special occasions.
column15: Children love getting presents at Christmas.

column14: To call or arrange for someone to arrive at a place.
column15: We got somebody to come and fix the kitchen light.

column14: To persuade or order someone to perform a task.
column15: What kind of things did your parents get you to do around the house?

column14: To be halted by an authority, especially the police.
column15: I never get stopped by the police because I’m a careful driver.

column14: To meet socially or gather as a group.
column15: We got together when we were at university.

column14: To have a haircut done by a hairdresser.
column15: How often do you usually get your hair cut ?

column14: A broader perspective on a situation, considering all aspects rather than just details.
column15: We need to see the bigger picture and not focus on the details.

column14: A decision or action that affects one's professional career development.
column15: I don't think going freelance is a very good career move .

column14: To continue doing something without stopping.
column15: Don't stop – carry on with what you're doing.

column14: To perform or complete a task, duty, or order.
column15: He's useless. He can't even carry out simple instructions.

column14: To attract someone's attention, often by making eye contact.
column15: We tried to catch the waiter's eye , but he ignored us.

column14: To think of an idea, plan, or solution.
column15: She came up with a brilliant solution to the problem.

column14: Family members who are not closely related, such as second cousins.
column15: We've got distant relatives in Australia.

column14: To wear formal or special clothes, or to put on a costume.
column15: The children love dressing up in their grandparents' clothes.

column14: To do exactly what is instructed, without deviation.
column15: I followed the instructions to the letter, but couldn't get the wi-fi to work.

column14: To visit a place, often to look at something of interest.
column15: Look out for the Picasso drawings when you go round the exhibition.

column14: An instinctive or intuitive feeling without logical reasoning.
column15: I've got a gut feeling that this meeting is going to go badly.

column14: Informal term for a man or boy.
column15: I've known him since school; he's a likeable guy .

column11: ˈhæv | ˈwənz | ˈnoʊz tə ðə ˈɡɹaɪnˌstoʊn

column14: To work very hard for a prolonged period.
column15: My brother's got his nose to the grindstone , revising for his exams.

column14: An emphatic way of expressing surprise or disbelief.
column15: How on earth could you spend $2,000 on a watch?

column14: To cause emotional pain or distress to someone.
column15: I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings.

column14: Destined to experience bad luck or misfortune.
column15: He seemed so ill-fated . He lost his job, and then his home in the same year.

column14: During the middle of the night, when it is very dark and quiet.
column15: I woke up suddenly in the dead of night – there was a noise downstairs.

column14: To dismiss workers from their jobs, often due to economic reasons.
column15: A thousand workers were laid off when the factory closed.

column14: To invent a story, excuse, or lie.
column15: He often makes up excuses for why he's late.

column14: When one almost remembers something but cannot quite recall it.
column15: It’s very annoying when a word is on the tip of your tongue , but you can’t quite remember it.

column14: A source of annoyance or frustration.
column15: This printer is such a pain in the neck – it never works.

column14: To learn something informally or quickly, often through exposure.
column15: He picks up languages very easily.

column14: To postpone or delay something to a later time.
column15: We should put off the meeting till next week.

column14: A tendency to become angry very easily.
column15: My grandfather has quite a quick temper.

column14: To need something because it is essential or necessary.
column15: This job requires a lot of attention to detail as there's so much data to record.

column14: To look like or be similar to someone or something.
column15: All the children strongly resembled their mother, with their curly hair and round eyes.

column14: A general or approximate plan for a trip or journey.
column15: I haven't really planned my trip yet, but I have a rough itinerary .

column14: To look for a safe place to stay, often due to danger or distress.
column15: After her marriage broke up, she sought refuge with friends.

column14: A brother or sister.
column15: He was an only child, but had always wanted a sibling.

column14: Expressing firm disagreement or resistance to something.
column15: We are strongly opposed to the government's new policy.

column14: To happen or develop in a particular way, often unexpectedly.
column15: The book sounded fascinating, but it turned out to be really dull.

column14: Experiencing stress due to demands or expectations.
column15: I'm not very good in a crisis. I hate being under pressure .

column14: Describes someone with very poor eyesight.
column15: Your mother is as blind as a bat. She should have her eyes tested.

column14: Describes someone who has significant hearing loss.
column15: My grandad is as deaf as a post, so you have to speak up a little.

column14: Describes a person who is in excellent health and physical condition.
column15: Thankfully, my grandmother is as fit as a fiddle . She's almost never ill.

column14: Describes a person, often a child, who behaves very well.
column15: She’s been as good as gold . She took all her medicine without complaining.

column14: Describes someone who moves or reacts extremely fast.
column15: When I pressed the button, the nurse came as quick as a flash .

column14: Describes someone very resistant to change or advice.
column15: My husband is as stubborn as a mule . He refuses to go to the doctor about his back problems.

column14: Describes a person who is extremely thin.
column15: He’s lost a lot of weight since his illness. He’s as thin as a rake .

column14: Describes a person who is very strong or resilient. Not realted to animals.
column15: My grandparents are in their 90s, but are both as tough as old boots.

column14: Describes someone who looks very pale, often due to fear or illness.
column15: She’s as white as a sheet . I think she’s going to faint.

column14: Describes someone who drinks large quantities of alcohol.
column15: He drinks like a fish . He really ought to cut down.

column14: Describes someone with a very large appetite.
column15: Some people can eat like a horse and not put on weight.

column14: Describes someone who sleeps very deeply and soundly.
column15: She sleeps like a log . I don’t think she’ll ever have problems with insomnia.

column14: Describes something that functions perfectly or efficiently.
column15: My new medication works like a dream . I feel so much better.
